docs.lead_paragraph: Iron, an essential nutrient, has long been the nation's most common nutritional deficiency. In decades past, many parents worried that children who were picky eaters would develop iron-deficiency anemia . My mother boiled meat I refused to eat and fed me the concentrated broth in hopes I'd get some of its iron.Now baby foods, infant formula and many other child-friendly foods, like breakfast cereals, breads, rice and pasta, are fortified with iron. Today iron deficiency is more likely in infants who are exclusively breast-fed, young children who consume too much milk, menstruating and pregnant women, vegans and strict vegetarians , and people who take medications that cause internal bleeding or interfere with iron absorption.

headline.main: Personal Health: A Host of Ills When Iron's Out of Balance

docs.abstract: Jane Brody Personal Health column, examining the dangers of both iron deficiency and overload, offers suggestions for how to balance one's iron intake; addresses dangers of high iron stores in the elderly, which can cause serious health problems. Drawing (M)

headline.main: A Host of Ills When Iron's Out of Balance
headline.print_headline: Personal Health: A Host of Ills When Iron’s Out of Balance

docs.abstract: Concerns about iron deficiency have eased with the wide availability of iron-fortified foods and drinks. Now more attention is being paid to the opposite problem: iron overload, which can cause serious problems, particularly in older people.
docs.snippet: Concerns about iron deficiency have eased with the wide availability of iron-fortified foods and drinks. Now more attention is being paid to the opposite problem: iron overload, which can cause serious problems, particularly in older people.

docs.lead_paragraph: Tomatoes, especially organically grown varieties, deliver a burst of nutrition with a flavor that’s synonymous with the south of France. Today: a Catalan-style open-faced sandwich with goat cheese.

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. William C. Reeves, an epidemiologist who fought his own federal agency to obtain money to study chronic fatigue syndrome and then infuriated patients with the ailment by suggesting that it was linked to psychological problems rather than a virus, died on Aug. 3 at his home in Atlanta. He was 69.The cause has not yet been determined, his son, Will, said.

headline.main: Dr. William C. Reeves Dies at 69; Sought Cause of Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
